repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: getreg("*") / getreg("+") disagree with registers (fixes https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/24257)
Solution: use a different mode for getting the register to avoid falling back if a register is unset

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    eq("", eval('getreg("*")'))
    eq("waddup", eval('getreg("+")'))
```
`eq` has a signature of `(expected, actual, context?)`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -752,4 +752,11 @@ describe('clipboard (with fake clipboard.vim)', function()
     expect('some some')
     eq('some', eval('getreg("*")'))
   end)
+
+  it('has correct value for clipboard registers #24257', function ()
+    eval('setreg("*", "")')
+    eval('setreg("+", "waddup")')
+    eq(eval('getreg("*")'), "")

comment_data.body: thank you for catching that! I'm new to writing lua tests
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -752,4 +752,11 @@ describe('clipboard (with fake clipboard.vim)', function()
     expect('some some')
     eq('some', eval('getreg("*")'))
   end)
+
+  it('has correct value for clipboard registers #24257', function ()
+    eval('setreg("*", "")')
+    eval('setreg("+", "waddup")')
+    eq(eval('getreg("*")'), "")

comment_data.body: On a non-X11 system where there is no distinction between `"*` and `"+`, those two registers are linked; so aren't they supposed to return the same register result `"waddup"`? How can the test pass (on macOS for example)?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -752,4 +752,11 @@ describe('clipboard (with fake clipboard.vim)', function()
     expect('some some')
     eq('some', eval('getreg("*")'))
   end)
+
+  it('has correct value for clipboard registers #24257', function ()
+    eval('setreg("*", "")')
+    eval('setreg("+", "waddup")')
+    eq("", eval('getreg("*")'))
+    eq("waddup", eval('getreg("+")'))

comment_data.body:
That's a great callout! Correct me if I'm wrong, but I don't think they're _necessarily_ linked, just linked by default. a user in MacOS could technically override `g:clipboard` to set them to do whatever they want. For example, `*` could be configured to use the tmux clipboard while `+` uses the system clipboard (source: [provider docs](https://neovim.io/doc/user/provider.html)).

I think the easiest way to avoid non-X11 weirdness in this test is to disable to clipboard provider, ensuring that `get_clipboard` will fail, then running this test, since it's really the clipboard registers that we're testing and not the clipboard provider.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -752,4 +752,11 @@ describe('clipboard (with fake clipboard.vim)', function()
     expect('some some')
     eq('some', eval('getreg("*")'))
   end)
+
+  it('has correct value for clipboard registers #24257', function ()
+    eval('setreg("*", "")')
+    eval('setreg("+", "waddup")')
+    eq("", eval('getreg("*")'))
+    eq("waddup", eval('getreg("+")'))

comment_data.body:
The test is wrong and has nothing to do with the issue.
```suggestion
  it('does not fall back to unnamed register with getreg() #24257', function ()
    eval('setreg("", "wrong")')
    command('let g:cliperror = 1')
    eq('', eval('getreg("*")'))
    eq('', eval('getreg("+")'))
  end)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -752,4 +752,13 @@ describe('clipboard (with fake clipboard.vim)', function()
     expect('some some')
     eq('some', eval('getreg("*")'))
   end)
+
+  it('has correct value for clipboard registers #24257', function ()
+    -- disable clipboard provider to test this behavior on non-X11 systems
+    command('let g:clipboard = ""')
+    eval('setreg("*", "")')
+    eval('setreg("+", "waddup")')
+    eq('', eval('getreg("*")'))
+    eq('waddup', eval('getreg("+")'))
+  end)

comment_data.body: This is definitely better more descriptive, since falling back to unnamed is the behavior we don't have to happen. My test accomplished the same thing because the second `setreg` sets the unnamed register to "waddup", but yours is more direct and readable 👍
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -752,4 +752,13 @@ describe('clipboard (with fake clipboard.vim)', function()
     expect('some some')
     eq('some', eval('getreg("*")'))
   end)
+
+  it('has correct value for clipboard registers #24257', function ()
+    -- disable clipboard provider to test this behavior on non-X11 systems
+    command('let g:clipboard = ""')
+    eval('setreg("*", "")')
+    eval('setreg("+", "waddup")')
+    eq('', eval('getreg("*")'))
+    eq('waddup', eval('getreg("+")'))
+  end)

comment_data.body: But you didn't set the unnamed register. You set the `+` register.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -752,4 +752,13 @@ describe('clipboard (with fake clipboard.vim)', function()
     expect('some some')
     eq('some', eval('getreg("*")'))
   end)
+
+  it('has correct value for clipboard registers #24257', function ()
+    -- disable clipboard provider to test this behavior on non-X11 systems
+    command('let g:clipboard = ""')
+    eval('setreg("*", "")')
+    eval('setreg("+", "waddup")')
+    eq('', eval('getreg("*")'))
+    eq('waddup', eval('getreg("+")'))
+  end)

comment_data.body: oh interesting, I thought the unnamed register would always be set as a result of setreg, but maybe that is not the case. i pretty much copied from that old issue. thank you!
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -752,4 +752,13 @@ describe('clipboard (with fake clipboard.vim)', function()
     expect('some some')
     eq('some', eval('getreg("*")'))
   end)
+
+  it('has correct value for clipboard registers #24257', function ()
+    -- disable clipboard provider to test this behavior on non-X11 systems
+    command('let g:clipboard = ""')
+    eval('setreg("*", "")')
+    eval('setreg("+", "waddup")')
+    eq('', eval('getreg("*")'))
+    eq('waddup', eval('getreg("+")'))
+  end)

comment_regular_data.body: I suspect some of the failing functional tests might have been relying on this behavior in `getreg`

> I suspect some of the failing functional tests might have been relying on this behavior in `getreg`

these were actually failing because I wasn't making `YREG_PUT` work the same way as `YREG_PASTE`,  but it should be fixed now.

the mac os tests are passing now, but the freebsd ones mysteriously fail. seems to not be related to this change though, since the test [I added passed](https://cirrus-ci.com/task/5148950529835008?logs=functionaltest#L2065)

title: fix(clipboard): make getreg accurate for clipboard registers
